<topcClas>General - Employment and labour</topcClas>       </subject>       <abstract><p>Abstract copyright UK Data Service and data collection copyright owner.</p>The <i>New Annual Survey Panel Dataset</i> (NESPD) contains the <i>New Earnings Survey</i> (NES) data (UK Data Archive SN 6704) in panel form. The NES is sampled on individuals whose National Insurance numbers end in a given pair of digits.  Since the same pair of terminating digits are used as the basis for each year's sample, a panel is automatically generated within the surveys.<br> <br> The NES is an annual survey of the earnings of employees in Great Britain. Its primary purpose is to obtain information about the levels, distribution and make-up of earnings, and for the collective agreements that cover them. It is designed to represent all categories of employees in businesses of all kinds and sizes. The questionnaire is directed to the employer, who completes it on the basis of payroll records for the employee. The earnings, hours of work and other information relate to a specified week in April of each year. The NESPD is a reduced form of the NES as it is based on a consistent variable sample.<br> <br> Please see the catalogue record for UK Data Archive SN 6704 for a fuller description of the NES.<br> <br> The third edition (October 2013) includes data for 2012.<br/></abstract>       <abstract><B>Main Topics</B>:<br>The NES and the NESPD include the following data for employees in all industries and occupations and for the major national collective agreements:<ul><li>levels, distributions and make-up of earnings</li><li>hours worked</li><li>industry</li><li>occupation</li><li>place of work</li><li>gender </li><li>age</li></ul></abstract>       <sumDscr>         <timePrd event="start" date="1975-01-01T00:00:00Z">1975</timePrd>         <timePrd event="end" (Metropolitan)</geogUnit>         <geogUnit>Districts (Non-metropolitan)</geogUnit>         <geogUnit>Government Office Regions</geogUnit>         <geogUnit>Unitary Authorities (England)</geogUnit> years residing and working in Great Britain in 1975-2012.</universe>         <dataKind>Alpha/numeric data</dataKind>         <dataKind> Individual (micro) level</dataKind>       </sumDscr> sample</sampProc>         <sampProc>One per cent sample of individuals from National Insurance records</sampProc>         <deviat>Approximately 160,000 to 180,000 individuals</deviat>         <collMode>Compilation or synthesis of existing material</collMode>         <collMode>Panel version of NES</collMode>         <sources />         <weight>No weighting used</weight>         <cleanOps>A</cleanOps>       </dataColl>     </method>     <dataAccs>       <setAvail>         <accsPlac>UK Data Service</accsPlac>       </setAvail>       <useStmt>         <specPerm>Secure data</specPerm>         <restrctn>Registration is required and standard conditions of use apply. The depositor may be informed about usage. Controlled data requirements and conditions also apply. Further information is available from <a href='http://ukdataservice.ac.uk/get-data/how-to-access/accesssecurelab.aspx'>Access to the Secure Lab</a>. In addition, the Service is required to request explicit permission from the data owner prior to providing the researcher with access to the data.<br> Available to UK HE/FE applicants only. <p>Please note:<br>Since these data are more sensitive and/or pose a higher risk of disclosure than data made available under the standard End User Licence or under a Special Licence, they are not available for download but may be accessed through Secure Access. Access requires accreditation by the UK Statistics Authority as an Approved Researcher, completion of face-to-face training, and agreement to the Secure Access's <a href='http://ukdataservice.ac.uk/media/176858/ukda140_sds_sdsagreement_public.pdf'>User Agreement</a> and <a href='http://ukdataservice.ac.uk/media/176861/UKDA142_SDS_SecurityBreaches_public.pdf'>Breaches Penalties Policy</a>. This is to ensure that the guarantee of confidentiality given to survey respondents is protected. Applications are screened by the UK Data Archive and the Office for National Statistics, and access is only granted to those researchers requiring data for statistical research purposes and who can justify their need for the data. Users who obtain access to these data are required to read and follow the <a href='http://www.data-archive.ac.uk/media/132701/UKDA171-SS-MicrodataHandling.pdf'> Microdata Handling and Security: Guide to Good Practice</a>.</restrctn>         <contact><a href=http://www.ukdataservice.ac.uk/help/get-in-touch.aspx>Get in touch</a></contact>       </useStmt>     </dataAccs>     <othrStdyMat>       <relStdy>6704 New Earnings Survey, 1986-2002: Secure Access </relStdy>       <relPubl>   </relPubl>       <relPubl>Tarasonis, L. (2013) <i>Three essays on wage information in imperfect labour markets</i>, unpublished Ph.D. thesis, University of Bristol.<br></relPubl>       <othRefs>Language Of Study Description: English</othRefs>       <othRefs>Language Of Study Documentation: English</othRefs>     </othrStdyMat>   </stdyDscr> </codeBook>
